title: How to Create a Hot Compress for Acne Treatment and Skin Health

steps.title: Use a bowl, sink, or some other temperature-safe container.
steps.content: Use a bowl, sink, or some other temperature-safe container. Run your faucet until the water heats up or put on a kettle to boil. Once the water is piping hot, add about 2 cups (470 mL) directly into your container and let it sit until it cools down to 100 °F (38 °C). [1] X Research source Use a thermometer for the most accurate reading, or wait until you can comfortably touch the water.

steps.title: Essential oils can soothe your skin and have antibacterial properties.
steps.content: Essential oils can soothe your skin and have antibacterial properties. [2] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source They also smell nice and can help you relax while you use the compress. Just add a few drops of either tea tree or lavender (or both) into your container of warm water. You can also use the water to brew black tea and use that for your compress. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Carefully soak the towel to not burn your hands.
steps.content: Carefully soak the towel to not burn your hands. If the water is still really hot, wait a few minutes to let it cool down. Think hot shower temperature—warm but not boiling. Take a clean washcloth and fully submerge it into the warm water so it’s completely saturated. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source If you don’t have a cotton washcloth, use a small towel or a microfiber cloth. Don’t use paper towels, which may fall apart and stick to your skin.

steps.title: Squeeze out water until the compress is damp and not dripping wet.
steps.content: Squeeze out water until the compress is damp and not dripping wet. Remove the cloth from the hot water once it’s fully soaked. Then, squeeze and twist it well. Get as much water out of it as you can so you’re left with a warm, damp compress. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Leave the compress on your pimples for 10-15 minutes.
steps.content: Leave the compress on your pimples for 10-15 minutes. Warm compresses are especially effective on deep, painful pimples that have developed into whiteheads, plus they can bring blind pimples to the surface. [6] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Don’t move the compress once you put it in place so it delivers consistent heat and moisture.

steps.title: Repeat the process to clear out pimples and help them heal.
steps.content: Repeat the process to clear out pimples and help them heal. The warmth from the compress helps draw out oil and bacteria trapped in your pimples and dissolves pus. [7] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Use a clean cloth and fresh water each time you make a warm compress so you don’t get any dirt or additional bacteria in your pimples.

steps.title: Use a pea-sized amount of acne medication on your pimples.
steps.content: Use a pea-sized amount of acne medication on your pimples. Wash your face with a daily acne cleanser and use a small amount of topical acne medications that contain ingredients such as benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, azelaic acid, or retinoids to knock out stubborn pimples. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Keeping your skin clean can get rid of any pimples you have and prevent new ones from developing. Using too much acne medication can irritate your skin and cause your problems to worsen. [9] X Research source If you have severe acne, make an appointment to see your doctor or a dermatologist. They can prescribe stronger medication to help treat your acne. [10] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
